deliberation: I examined expressions like “He called loudly in my hearing” (וַיִּקְרָא בְאָזְנַי קוֹל גָּדוֹל) and “each bearing his weapons of destruction.” These are intense and vivid but function as straightforward narrative description of the visionary scene, not as metaphors, similes, or idioms beyond normal Hebrew collocation. No distinct figurative device from the requested types appears.

The six men with smashing weapons and the one in linen with a scribe’s inkhorn are symbolic within the vision, but linguistically they are described in literal terms (men, gate, altar, bronze). There is no metaphorical or idiomatic expression in the Hebrew; the verse simply reports what Ezekiel sees.

I considered whether the movement of the “glory of the God of Israel” (כְּבוֹד אֱלֹהֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל) is literal within the vision or figurative. In Ezekiel this ‘glory’ is a visible manifestation, yet linguistically ‘glory’ still functions as a metonymy for God’s active presence. Thus I identify a metonymic expression, not a simple metaphor or simile.

instances.explanation: The term “glory of the God of Israel” functions metonymically: the ‘glory’ (radiant manifestation) stands for God’s own operative presence relocating within the temple structure.

deliberation: I examined “put a mark on the foreheads” and the description of those who “moan and groan” over abominations. While the mark is symbolically protective in the broader vision, the wording itself is literal within the visionary frame, and the emotional verbs are straightforward. No clear metaphor, simile, idiom, or metonymy appears in the Hebrew phrasing here.

I focused on the idiomatic command, “אַל־תָּחֹס עֵינְכֶם” (literally, ‘let your eye not spare’). The ‘eye’ is used as a metonym for pity or favorable regard; this is a conventional Hebrew idiom and a clear case of metonymy. The rest of the verse (“and do not have compassion”) is semantically parallel but not itself figurative.

instances.explanation: The phrase uses ‘eye’ metonymically for compassion; to let one’s eye ‘spare’ is a Hebrew idiom for showing mercy. Here they are instructed that their ‘eyes’ are not to spare, i.e., they must show no pity.

deliberation: I considered the catalogue “old man, youth and maiden, children and women” (זָקֵן בָּחוּר וּבְתוּלָה וְטַף וְנָשִׁים) as a possible merism or totalizing rhetoric. It lists diverse age and gender groups to express comprehensiveness of the slaughter, functioning hyperbolically to indicate ‘everyone’ rather than merely those specific subsets.

deliberation: I focused on “fill the courts with the slain” (וּמַלְאוּ אֶת־הַחֲצֵרוֹת חֲלָלִים). The verb ‘fill’ combined with the noun ‘slain’ evokes an image of temple courts packed with corpses. This is strongly hyperbolic to express extreme carnage, though within the vision it may also be visually realized.

instances.explanation: The charge to ‘fill the courts with the slain’ uses the imagery of complete spatial filling to hyperbolically express the massive, desecrating bloodshed that will overrun the temple precincts.

deliberation: I considered Ezekiel’s physical reaction (‘I fell on my face’) as a conventional gesture rather than figurative. The key figurative expression is “בְּשָׁפְכְּךָ אֶת־חֲמָתְךָ” (‘when you pour out your wrath’), which clearly treats divine anger as a liquid that can be poured onto Jerusalem—a standard Hebrew metaphor for judgment.

deliberation: I noted the parallel phrases “the land is full of bloods” (וַתִּמָּלֵא הָאָרֶץ דָּמִים) and “the city is full of מֻטֶּה (injustice/perversion).” ‘Bloods’ is a metonym for murder and violent crime, and ‘full’ is hyperbolic spatial imagery of moral saturation. The second clause repeats the fullness imagery for a different moral category. I treat these as two closely related but distinct figurative expressions.

deliberation: Two expressions stand out: (1) “My eye will not spare” (לֹא־תָחוֹס עֵינִי), a repetition of the eye-metonymy for pity, and (2) “דַּרְכָּם בְּרֹאשָׁם נָתָתִּי” (‘I have put their way on their head’), an idiomatic metaphor for retributive justice, picturing their conduct as something placed back upon them.
